environments.name: Abandoned Grove
environments.description: A former druidic grove lying fallow and fully reclaimed by nature.
potentialAdversaries: Grove Guardians (Minor Treant, Sylvan Soldier, Young Dryad)

features.name: Overgrown Battlefield
features.description: There has been a battle here. A PC can make an Instinct Roll to identify evidence of that fight. On a success with Hope, learn all three pieces of information below. On a success with Fear, learn two. On a failure, a PC can mark a Stress to learn one and gain advantage on the next action roll to investigate this environment. A PC with an appropriate background or Experience can learn an additional detail and ask a follow-up question about the scene and get a truthful (if not always complete) answer.
details: Traces of a battle (broken weapons and branches, gouges in the ground) litter the ground.
A moss-covered tree trunk is actually the corpse of a treant.
Still-standing trees are twisted in strange ways, as if by powerful magic.
prompts: Why did these groups come to blows?
Why is the grove unused now?

features.name: Barbed Vines
features.description: Pick a point within the grove. All targets within Very Close range of that point must succeed on an Agility Reaction Roll or take 1d8+3 physical damage and become Restrained by barbed vines. Restrained lasts until they're freed with a successful Finesse or Strength roll or by dealing at least 6 damage to the vines.
prompts: How many vines are there?
Where do they grab you?
Do they pull you down or lift you off the ground?

features.name: You Are Not Welcome Here
features.description: A Young Dryad, two Sylvan Soldiers, and a number of Minor Treants equal to the number of PCs appear to confront the party for their intrusion.
prompts: What are the grove guardians concealing?
What threat to the forest could the PCs confront to appease the Dryad?

features.name: Defiler
features.description: Spend a Fear to summon a Minor Chaos Elemental drawn to the echoes of violence and discord. They appear within Far range of a chosen PC and immediately take the spotlight.
prompts: What color does the grass turn as the elemental appears?
How does the chaos warp insects and small wildlife within the grove?

environments.name: Ambushed
environments.description: An ambush is set to catch an unsuspecting party off-guard.

features.name: Relative Strength
features.description: The Difficulty of this environment equals that of the adversary with the highest Difficulty.
prompts: Who cues the ambush?
What makes it clear they're in charge?

features.name: Surprise!
features.description: The ambushers reveal themselves to the party, you gain 2 Fear, and the spotlight immediately shifts to one of the ambushing adversaries.
prompts: What do the ambushers want from the party?
How do their tactics in the ambush reflect that?

environments.name: Ambushers
environments.description: An ambush is set by the PCs to catch unsuspecting adversaries off-guard.

features.name: Relative Strength
features.description: The Difficulty of this environment equals that of the adversary with the highest Difficulty.
prompts: Which adversary is the least prepared?
Which one is the most?

features.name: Where Did They Come From?
features.description: When a PC starts the ambush on unsuspecting adversaries, you lose 2 Fear and the first attack roll a PC makes has advantage.
prompts: What are the adversaries in the middle of doing when the ambush starts?
How does this impact their approach to the fight?

environments.name: Bustling Marketplace
environments.description: The economic heart of the settlement, with local artisans, traveling merchants, and patrons across social classes.
impulses: tempt and tantalize with wares from near and far

features.name: Tip the Scales
features.description: PCs can gain advantage on a Presence Roll by offering a handful of gold as part of the interaction.
prompts: Will any coin be accepted, or only local currency?
How overt are the PCs in offering this bribe?

features.name: Unexpected Find
features.description: Reveal to the PCs that one of the merchants has something they want or need, such as food from their home, a rare book, magical components, a dubious treasure map, or a magical key.
prompts: What cost beyond gold will the merchant ask for in exchange for this rarity?

features.name: Sticky Fingers
features.description: A thief tries to steal something from a PC. The PC must succeed on an Instinct Roll to notice the thief or lose an item of the GM's choice as the thief escapes to a Close distance. To retrieve the stolen item, the PCs must complete a Progress Countdown (6) to chase down the thief before the thief completes a Consequence Countdown (4) and escapes to their hideout.
prompts: What drove this person to pickpocketing?
Where is the thief's hideout and how has it avoided notice?

features.name: Crowd Closes In
features.description: When one of the PCs splits from the group, the crowds shift and cut them off from the party.
prompts: Where does the crowd's movement carry them?
How do they feel about being alone but surrounded?

environments.name: Cliffside Ascent
environments.description: A steep, rocky cliff side tall enough to make traversal dangerous.
impulses: Cast the unready down to a rocky doom
draw people in with promise of what lies at the top

features.name: The Climb
features.description: Climbing up the cliff side uses a Progress Countdown (12). It ticks down according to the following criteria when the PCs make an action roll to climb: Critical Success: Tick down 3, Success with Hope: Tick down 2, Success with Fear: Tick down 1, Failure with Hope: No advancement, Failure with Fear: Tick up 1. When the countdown triggers, the party has made it to the top of the cliff.
prompts: What strange formations are the stones arranged in?
What ominous warnings did previous adventurers leave?

features.name: Pitons Left Behind
features.description: Previous climbers left behind large metal rods that climbers can use to aid their ascent. If a PC using the pitons fails an action roll to climb, they can mark a Stress instead of ticking the countdown up.
prompts: What do the shape and material of these pitons tell you about the previous climbers?
How far apart are they from one another?

features.name: Fall
features.description: Spend a Fear to have a PC's handhold fail, plummeting them toward the ground. If they aren't saved on the next action, they hit the ground and tick up the countdown by 2. The PC takes 1d12 physical damage if the countdown is between 8 and 12, 2d12 between 4 and 7, and 3d12 at 3 or lower.
prompts: How can you tell many others have fallen here before?
What lives in these walls that might try to scare adventurers into falling for an easy meal?

environments.name: Local Tavern
environments.description: A lively tavern that serves as the social hub for its town.

features.name: What's the Talk of the Town?
features.description: A PC can ask the bartender, staff, or patrons about local events, rumors, and potential work with a Presence Roll. On a success, they can pick two of the below details to learn—or three if they critically succeed. On a failure, they can pick one and mark a Stress as the local carries on about something irrelevant.
details: A fascinating rumor with a connection to a PC's background
A promising job for the party involving a nearby threat or situation
Local folklore that relates to something they've seen
Town gossip that hints at a community problem
prompts: Who has what kind of information?
What gossip do the locals start spreading about the PCs?

features.name: Sing For Your Supper
features.description: A PC can perform one time for the guests by making a Presence Roll. On a success, they earn 1d4 handfuls of gold (2d4 if they critically succeed). On a failure, they mark a Stress.
prompts: What piece do you perform?
What does that piece mean to you?
When's the last time you performed it for a crowd?

features.name: Mysterious Stranger
features.description: Reveal a stranger concealing their identity, lurking in a shaded booth.
prompts: What do they want?
What's their impression of the PCs?
What mannerisms or accessories do they have?

features.name: Someone Comes to Town
features.description: Introduce a significant NPC who wants to hire the party for something or who relates to a PC's background.
prompts: Did they know the PCs were here?
What do they want in this town?

features.name: Bar Fight!
features.description: Spend a Fear to have a bar fight erupt in the tavern. When a PC tries to move through the tavern while the fight persists, they must succeed on an Agility or Presence Roll or take 1d6+2 physical damage from a wild swing or thrown object. A PC can try to activate this feature by succeeding on an action roll that would provoke tavern patrons.
prompts: Who started the fight?
What will it take to stop it?

environments.name: Outpost Town
environments.description: A small town on the outskirts of a nation or region, close to a dungeon, tombs, or other adventuring destinations.
impulses: Drive the desperate to certain doom
potentialAdversaries: Jagged Knife Bandits (Hexer, Kneebreaker, Lackey, Lieutenant, Shadow, Sniper)

features.name: Rumors Abound
features.description: Gossip is the fastest-traveling currency in the realm. A PC can inquire about major events by making a Presence Roll. What they learn depends on the outcome of their roll: Critical Success: Learn about two major events. The PC can ask one follow-up question about one of the rumors and get a truthful (if not always complete) answer. Success with Hope: Learn about two events, at least one of which is relevant to the character's background. Success with Fear: Learn an alarming rumor related to the character's background. Any Failure: The locals respond poorly to their inquiries. The PC must mark a Stress to learn one relevant rumor.
prompts: What news do the PCs have that they could pass along to curious travelers?
What do the locals think about these events?

features.name: Society of the Broken Compass
features.description: An adventuring society maintains a chapterhouse here, where heroes trade boasts and rumors, drink to their imagined successes, and scheme to undermine their rivals.
prompts: What boasts do the adventurers here make, and which do you think are true?

features.name: Rival Party
features.description: Another adventuring party is here, seeking the same treasure or leads as the PCs.
prompts: Which PC has a connection to one of the rival party members?
Do they approach the PC first or do they wait for the PC to move?

features.name: It'd Be a Shame If Something Happened to Your Store
features.description: The PCs witness as agents of a local crime boss shake down a general goods store.
prompts: What trouble does it cause if the PCs intervene?

features.name: Wrong Place, Wrong Time
features.description: At night, or when the party is alone in a back alley, you can spend a Fear to introduce a group of thieves who try to rob them. The thieves appear at Close range of a chosen PC and include a Jagged Knife Kneebreaker, as many Lackeys as there are PCs, and a Lieutenant. For a larger party, add a Hexer or Sniper.
prompts: What details show the party that these people are desperate former adventurers?

environments.name: Raging River
environments.description: A swift-moving river without a bridge crossing, deep enough to sweep away most people.
potentialAdversaries: Jagged Knife Bandits (Hexer, Kneebreaker, Lackey, Lieutenant, Shadow, Sniper)

features.name: Dangerous Crossing
features.description: Crossing the river requires the party to complete a Progress Countdown (4). A PC who rolls a failure with Fear is immediately targeted by the 'Undertow' action without requiring a Fear to be spent on the feature.
prompts: Have any of the PCs forded rivers like this before?
Are any of them afraid of drowning?

features.name: Undertow
features.description: Spend a Fear to catch a PC in the undertow. They must make an Agility Reaction Roll. On a failure, they take 1d6+1 physical damage and are moved a Close distance down the river, becoming Vulnerable until they get out of the river. On a success, they must mark a Stress.
prompts: What trinkets and baubles lie along the bottom of the riverbed?
Do predators swim these rivers?

features.name: Patient Hunter
features.description: Spend a Fear to summon a Glass Snake within Close range of a chosen PC. The Snake appears in or near the river and immediately takes the spotlight to use their 'Spinning Serpent' action.
prompts: What treasures does the beast have in their burrow?
What travelers have already fallen victim to this predator?

environments.name: Cult Ritual
environments.description: A Fallen cult assembles around a sigil of the defeated gods and a bonfire that burns a sickly shade of green.
impulses: unite the Mortal Realm with the Circles Below
potentialAdversaries: Cult of the Fallen (Cult Adept, Cult Fang, Cult Initiate, Secret-Keeper)

features.name: Desecrated Ground
features.description: Cultists dedicated this place to the Fallen Gods, and their foul influence seeps into it. Reduce the PCs' Hope Die to a d10 while in this environment. The desecration can be removed with a Progress Countdown (6).
prompts: How do the PCs first notice that something is wrong about this place?
What fears resurface while hope is kept at bay?

features.name: Blasphemous Might
features.description: A portion of the ritual's power is diverted into a cult member to fight off interlopers. Choose one adversary to become Imbued with terrible magic until the scene ends or they're defeated. An Imbued adversary immediately takes the spotlight and gains one of the following benefits, or all three if you spend a Fear: They gain advantage on all attacks, they deal an extra 1d10 damage on a successful attack, or they gain the following feature: Relentless (2) - Passive. This adversary can be spotlighted up to two times per GM turn. Spend Fear as usual to spotlight them.
prompts: How does the enemy change in appearance?
What fears do their blows bring to the surface?

features.name: The Summoning
features.description: Countdown (6). When the PCs enter the scene or the cult begins the ritual to summon a demon, activate the countdown. Designate one adversary to lead the ritual. The countdown ticks down when a PC rolls with Fear. When it triggers, summon a Minor Demon within Very Close range of the ritual's leader. If the leader is defeated, the countdown ends with no effect as the ritual fails.
prompts: What will the cult do with this leashed demon if they succeed?
What will they try to summon next?

features.name: Complete the Ritual
features.description: If the ritual's leader is targeted by an attack or spell, an ally within Very Close range of them can mark a Stress to be targeted by that attack or spell instead.
prompts: What does it feel like to see such devotion turned to the pursuit of fear and domination?

environments.name: Hallowed Temple
environments.description: A bustling but well-kept temple that provides healing and hosts regular services, overseen by a priest or seraph.
impulses: Connect the Mortal Realm with the Hallows Above
display the power of the divine
provide aid and succor to the faithful
potentialAdversaries: Guards (Archer Guard, Bladed Guard, Head Guard)

features.name: A Place of Healing
features.description: A PC who takes a rest in the Hallowed Temple automatically clears all HP.
prompts: What does the incense smell like?
What kinds of songs do the acolytes sing?

features.name: Divine Guidance
features.description: A PC who prays to a deity while in the Hallowed Temple can make an Instinct Roll to receive answers. If the god they beseech isn't welcome in this temple, the roll is made with disadvantage. Critical Success: The PC gains clear information. Additionally, they gain 1d4 Hope, which can be distributed between the party if they share the vision and guidance they received. Success with Hope: The PC receives clear information. Success with Fear: The PC receives brief flashes of insight and an emotional impression conveying an answer. Any Failure: The PC receives only vague flashes. They can mark a Stress to receive one clear image without context.
prompts: What does it feel like as you are touched by this vision?
What feeling lingers after the images have passed?

features.name: Relentless Hope
features.description: Once per scene, each PC can mark a Stress to turn a result with Fear into a result with Hope.
prompts: What emotions or memories do you connect with when fear presses in?

features.name: Divine Censure
features.description: When the PCs have trespassed, blasphemed, or offended the clergy, you can spend a Fear to summon a High Seraph and 1d4 Bladed Guards within Close range of the senior priest to reinforce their will.
prompts: What symbols or icons do they bear that signal they are anointed agents of the divinity?
Who leads the group and what led them to this calling?

environments.name: Haunted City
environments.description: An abandoned city populated by the restless spirits of eras past.
impulses: replay apocalypses both public and personal
potentialAdversaries: Ghosts (Spectral Archer, Spectral Captain, Spectral Guardian)
ghostly versions of other adversaries (see Ghostly Form)

features.name: Buried Knowledge
features.description: The city has countless mysteries to unfold. A PC who seeks knowledge about the fallen city can make an Instinct or Knowledge Roll to learn about this place and discover (potentially haunted) loot. Critical Success: Gain valuable information and a related useful item. Success with Hope: Gain valuable information. Success with Fear: Uncover vague or incomplete information. Any Failure: Mark a Stress to find a lead after an exhaustive search.
prompts: What greater secrets does the city contain?
Why have so many ghosts lingered here?
What doomed adventurers have met a bad fate here already?

features.name: Ghostly Form
features.description: Adversaries who appear here are of a ghostly form. They have resistance to physical damage and can mark a Stress to move up to Close range through solid objects.
prompts: What injuries to their physical form speak to their cause of death?
What unfulfilled purpose holds them in the Mortal Plane?

features.name: Dead Ends
features.description: The ghosts of an earlier era manifest scenes from their bygone era, such as a street festival, a revolution, or a heist. These hauntings change the layout of the city around the PCs, blocking the way behind them, forcing a detour, or presenting them with a challenge, such as mistaking them for rival thieves during the heist.
prompts: What do the ghosts want from you?
What do you need from them?

features.name: Apocalypse Then
features.description: Spend a Fear to manifest the echo of a past disaster that ravaged the city. Activate a Progress Countdown (5) as the disaster replays around the PCs. To complete the countdown and escape the catastrophe, the PCs must overcome threats such as rampaging fires, stampeding civilians, collapsing buildings, or crumbling streets, while recalling history and finding clues to escape the inevitable.
prompts: Is this the disaster that led the city to be abandoned?
What is known about this disaster, and how could that help the PCs escape?

environments.name: Mountain Pass
environments.description: Stony peaks that pierce the clouds, with a twisting path winding its way up and over through many switchbacks.
impulses: Exact a chilling toll in supplies and stamina

features.name: Engraved Sigils
features.description: Large markings and engravings have been made in the mountainside. A PC with a relevant background or Experience identifies them as weather magic increasing the power of the icy winds. A PC who succeeds on a Knowledge Roll can recall information about the sigils, potential information about their creators, and the knowledge of how to dispel them. If a PC critically succeeds, they recognize that the sigils are of a style created by ridgeborne enchanters and they gain advantage on a roll to dispel the sigils.
prompts: Who laid this enchantment?
Are they nearby?
Why did they want the weather to be more daunting?

features.name: Avalanche
features.description: Spend a Fear to carve the mountain with an icy torrent, causing an avalanche. All PCs in its path must succeed on an Agility or Strength Reaction Roll or be bowled over and carried down the mountain. A PC using rope, pitons, or other climbing gear gains advantage on this roll. Targets who fail are knocked down the mountain to Far range, take 2d20 physical damage, and must mark a Stress. Targets who succeed must mark a Stress.
prompts: How do the PCs try to weather the avalanche?
What approach do the characters take to find one another when their companions go hurtling down the mountainside?

features.name: Raptor Nest
features.description: When the PCs enter the raptors' hunting grounds, two Giant Eagles appear at Very Far range of a chosen PC, identifying the PCs as likely prey.
prompts: How long has it been since the eagles last found prey?
Do they have eggs in their nest, or unfl edged young?

features.name: Icy Winds
features.description: Countdown (Loop 4). When the PCs enter the mountain pass, activate the countdown. When it triggers, all characters traveling through the pass must succeed on a Strength Reaction Roll or mark a Stress. A PC wearing clothes appropriate for extreme cold gains advantage on these rolls.
prompts: What parts of the PC's bodies go numb first?
How do they try to keep warm as they press forward?

environments.name: Ancient Library
environments.description: A vast repository of forgotten knowledge, with towering shelves and ancient tomes.

features.name: Forbidden Tomes
features.description: Ancient texts contain dangerous knowledge. A PC can attempt to read a forbidden tome with a Knowledge Roll. On a success, they gain valuable information but must mark a Stress. On a failure, they take 2d8 psychic damage and mark a Stress.
prompts: What dark secrets do these tomes contain?
Who would want this knowledge kept hidden?

features.name: Living Shelves
features.description: Spend a Fear to have the library's shelves shift and rearrange, trapping PCs in maze-like corridors. PCs must succeed on a Knowledge Roll to navigate or mark a Stress.
prompts: How do the shelves move?
What patterns emerge in their arrangement?

features.name: Knowledge Drain
features.description: When a PC fails a Knowledge Roll, the library drains their memories. They lose access to one Experience or background feature until they complete a Progress Countdown (8).
prompts: What memories are being stolen?
How does it feel to lose part of yourself?

environments.name: Blighted Forest
environments.description: A corrupted woodland where nature has been twisted by dark magic.

features.name: Blight Spread
features.description: The corruption spreads through contact. PCs who touch blighted areas must succeed on a Constitution Roll or take 1d6 poison damage and mark a Stress.
prompts: How does the blight manifest visually?
What does it feel like to be touched by corruption?

features.name: Corrupted Wildlife
features.description: Spend a Fear to summon corrupted versions of normal forest creatures. They deal extra poison damage and can spread blight.
prompts: How have these creatures been changed?
What drives their corrupted behavior?

features.name: Purification Ritual
features.description: PCs can attempt to purify blighted areas with a Religion Roll. Success creates safe zones, but failure spreads the blight further.
prompts: What does purification look like?
How do you know if it's working?

environments.name: Crystal Caverns
environments.description: A network of caves filled with luminescent crystals that pulse with magical energy.

features.name: Crystal Resonance
features.description: Crystals amplify magical effects. Spells cast here have their damage increased by 1d6, but the caster must succeed on a Constitution Roll or take 1d4 psychic damage.
prompts: How do the crystals react to magic?
What colors do they pulse with?

features.name: Energy Drain
features.description: Spend a Fear to have crystals drain magical energy from nearby creatures. PCs must succeed on a Constitution Roll or lose access to their highest-level spell until they rest.
prompts: How does it feel to have your magic drained?
What happens to the drained energy?

features.name: Crystal Maze
features.description: When PCs become disoriented, the crystals create illusory passages. They must succeed on an Investigation Roll to find the real path or become lost.
prompts: How do you distinguish real from illusion?
What patterns emerge in the crystal formations?

environments.name: Floating Islands
environments.description: A series of islands suspended in the sky, connected by precarious bridges and magical currents.

features.name: Wind Currents
features.description: Strong winds buffet the islands. PCs must succeed on an Acrobatics Roll to move between islands or risk being blown off course.
prompts: How do the wind patterns change?
What happens if you're caught in a strong gust?

features.name: Fragile Bridges
features.description: Spend a Fear to have a bridge begin to crumble. PCs must quickly cross or find an alternative route. Failure results in falling damage.
prompts: How do you know a bridge is unstable?
What alternatives exist for crossing?

features.name: Sky Pirates
features.description: When PCs are vulnerable on a bridge, sky pirates may appear to ambush them. They seek treasure and magical items.
prompts: How do the pirates approach?
What do they want from the party?

environments.name: Celestial Realm
environments.description: A plane of pure light and divine energy, where the laws of reality bend to celestial will.

features.name: Divine Aura
features.description: The realm's pure energy affects all within it. Evil-aligned creatures take 2d8 radiant damage per round, while good-aligned creatures gain advantage on all rolls.
prompts: How does the divine energy feel?
What happens to those unworthy of this realm?

features.name: Reality Warp
features.description: Spend a Fear to alter the fundamental laws of reality in a localized area. Gravity, time, or space may be affected, requiring PCs to adapt quickly.
prompts: How does reality change?
What rules govern this new reality?

features.name: Divine Judgment
features.description: When PCs commit acts against their alignment, the realm judges them. They must succeed on a Charisma Roll or face consequences based on their actions.
prompts: How does the realm judge actions?
What consequences await the guilty?

environments.name: Demonic Portal
environments.description: A gateway to the Abyss, spewing forth demonic energy and corrupting all it touches.

features.name: Corruption Field
features.description: The portal's energy corrupts all within range. PCs must succeed on a Constitution Roll each round or take 1d8 necrotic damage and risk corruption.
prompts: How does corruption manifest?
What happens to those fully corrupted?

features.name: Demonic Summoning
features.description: Spend a Fear to summon demons from the portal. The number and strength depend on how much Fear is spent.
prompts: What types of demons emerge?
How do they react to the mortal realm?

features.name: Portal Instability
features.description: The portal's energy fluctuates unpredictably. PCs must succeed on a Dexterity Roll or be affected by random magical effects.
prompts: How does the portal behave?
What warning signs precede instability?

environments.name: Time Distortion
environments.description: A region where time flows differently, creating temporal anomalies and paradoxes.

features.name: Temporal Flux
features.description: Time flows at different rates in different areas. PCs may age rapidly, move slowly, or experience time loops.
prompts: How does time behave here?
What are the consequences of temporal manipulation?

features.name: Time Loop
features.description: Spend a Fear to create a localized time loop. PCs must find a way to break the loop or repeat the same events indefinitely.
prompts: What triggers the time loop?
How do you break free from it?

features.name: Temporal Paradox
features.description: When PCs create logical contradictions, temporal paradoxes occur. Reality becomes unstable until the paradox is resolved.
prompts: What paradox was created?
How can it be resolved?

environments.name: Void Rift
environments.description: A tear in reality leading to the void between worlds, where nothingness consumes all.

features.name: Void Corruption
features.description: The void's influence corrupts reality itself. PCs must succeed on a Wisdom Roll or begin to fade from existence.
prompts: How does the void affect reality?
What happens to those who fade away?

features.name: Reality Tear
features.description: Spend a Fear to expand the rift, consuming more of the surrounding area. PCs must find a way to seal it or risk losing everything.
prompts: How does the rift expand?
What can stop its growth?

features.name: Void Manifestation
features.description: When the void's influence grows strong enough, void entities manifest to consume the remaining reality.
prompts: What do these entities look like?
How do they consume reality?
